posts.name: Tom Line
posts.cooked:
We have had more problems with the Rio this year than we’ve ever seen before.   In our first competition, a Roborio 1 that had been working fine decided that on boot, on the field, it would start crashing while loading code over and over again.  Power cycling did not fix it, and it required us to connect to the Rio via USB and redeploy code once in the pits.

We’ve seen it happen twice now in two days - and this is with a different robot and Rio 1.  The robot can be fine.  We change a battery, or power cycle, and it goes into this boot loop.

I’m concerned it might happen at our competition (again) and we are planning on having multiple roborios with code deployed that we can drop in.

Has anyone seen similar behavior?

The only thing I can think of that we are doing that we haven’t done is using labview to open config files.  In the past we always used text files. But that doesn’t seem like it should cause this problem, and it works fine 98% of the time.

posts.name: Mark McLeod
posts.cooked:
Want to share your code in case we can repeat the issue?

What firmware is on that RIO 1?

posts.name: Justin Tervay
posts.cooked:
Is it this issue?

Build Successful but not deploying Programming

Build successful but no robot code after deploying Technical

link_counts.title: Build successful but no robot code after deploying

posts.name: Tom Line
posts.cooked: No.  We have no problem deploying code initially.  We can run indefinitely on that code without a problem.  Then, on some random power cycle, it will start crashing over and over.  Because of the crashing, the roborio cpu never enters a state where we can connect over wireless/ethernet, and forces us to connect via USB.  Even then, it will take 3 or 4 tries before we can get in between the ‘reboots’ to deploy code.

posts.name: Tom Line
posts.cooked:
It has the newest firmware.  We are uploading our latest to github.

Contribute to frc1718/2022-Robot-Code development by creating an account on GitHub.

posts.name: Mark McLeod
posts.cooked:
I’m sure it’s the newest. There are however two current versions. One for the roboRIO 1.0 (6) and another for the roboRIO 2.0 (8) They will both work on a RIO 1 to a point. It’s the point where it stops working that can be aggravating.

Which version of the firmware are you running?

posts.name: Tom Line
posts.cooked:
Verified just now, roborio version 4.  (Not roborio 2).

This one.

posts.name: Mark McLeod
posts.cooked:
Hopefully that’s v4.0 of the image not the firmware. In this picture the Image is v4.0 The firmware is version 6.0.0f1 We want to look at the listings on the left side. 2022 RIO 1.0 Image and Firmware 901×519 42.8 KB

2022 RIO 1.0 Image and Firmware 901×519 42.8 KB

2022 RIO 1.0 Image and Firmware 901×519 42.8 KB

posts.name: Mark McLeod
posts.cooked:
The project is missing some dependencies:

SWERVE_DRIVE_ODOMETRY.ctl

PathPlannerTrajectory.ctl

SWERVE_DRIVE_KINEMATICS.ctl

Util_GetTime.vi

etc

Is there a vendor library I need to download?

posts.name: Tom Line
posts.cooked: Jsimspso’s trajectory library.  We use it because it has easy access to the FPGA high precision timer (which we didn’t know how to access until he released it).  We also were using it for trajectory running early on, and plan on returning to it once the season is over for more development.

posts.name: Tom Line
posts.cooked:
Sure enough!  Firmware version 8 on a roborio 1.

installing the correct firmware and reimaging it now.

posts.name: Mark McLeod
posts.cooked:
It’s such a simple thing sometimes…

Be careful, there are still bugs out there…

posts.name: Tom Line
posts.cooked: My controls lead is currently complaining because the firmware aren’t labled as roborio 1 and roborio 2.  I told him to read the directions next time =).

posts.name: Tom Line
posts.cooked: Well, that was short-lived.  Reimaged, reformatted, and on the third reboot it’s back in a boot loop.

posts.name: Mark McLeod
posts.cooked: I’ll try running your code here.

posts.name: Mark McLeod
posts.cooked:
Added Jim Simpsons library, but still missing:

PathPlannerTrajectory.ctl

Sound familiar? It may be due to a specific version of the trajectory library.

posts.name: Tom Line
posts.cooked:
There are two installs on that path planner page.  I believe you need both.

Both 2020 packages.

posts.name: Mark McLeod
posts.cooked:
Did you create this auton scripts file? Can you send me a sample one to load? /home/lvuser/Auton ScriptsLabVIEW

I’m getting a bunch of errors when running it that I have to track down. Some are just the specific CAN IDs missing since I don’t have all your devices, or set to the same CAN IDs. Others are missing RefNums

How are you rebooting to get the error? Power cycle or the DS “Reboot roboRIO” button?

posts.name: Tom Line
posts.cooked: The scripts are csvs located in the disabled/auton/scripts directory or near there.  The configuration files are on the disabled/config directory I believe.

posts.name: Tom Line
posts.cooked: We power cycle (main breaker) and it sometimes happens, sometimes doesn’t.  We have seen it 3 times in two days.
